Award.AwardTitle: Planning Visit to Korea: A Catalyst for Collaboration on Civil Infrastructure Research Involving Monitored Data
Award.AbstractNarration:
This planning visit is to use monitoring data collected from various structural systems in Korea in order to apply, validate, and test non-parametric methodologies. Without a priori information or physical assumptions on the structures of interest, which requires expensive field/laboratory measurements, non-parametric methodologies can be used to make useful engineering judgments using data from a minimal number of sensors. Unlike the US, the monitoring of important civil infrastructure in Korea is mandated by laws, and access to our Korean counterparts? rich data pools will be important to developing and validating the methodologies.

This visit and the ensuing research efforts will positively impact how voluminous sensor data can be meaningfully and accurately interpreted. Its importance is highly emphasized in the current development of the Long-Term Bridge Performance (LTBP) Program by FHWA and the Landslide Hazards Program by USGS. This planning visit is to catalyze international research collaborations, and it is expected to yield ongoing research ventures in the near future. Monitoring civil infrastructure using sensor-based instrumentation is highly multi-disciplinary, and the graduate student involved in this planning visit will have a unique opportunity of being exposed to real-life needs of multi-disciplinary research.

Institution.Name: The University of Central Florida Board of Trustees
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CENTRAL FLORIDA BOARD OF TRUSTEES, THE

Performance_Institution.Name: The University of Central Florida Board of Trustees

POR.DRECONTENT:
Restoring and improving urban infrastructure is recognized by NAE as one of the Grand Challenges for engineering. The current condition of U.S. infrastructure is rated “D” according the 2009 ASCE Report Cards for America’s Civil Infrastructure. A grand challenge is that the current infrastructure management approach is not sustainable. The estimated cost to improve the deficient U.S. infrastructure system has increased approximately double for last ten years: $1.3 trillion in 2001, $1.6 trillion in 2003, and $2.2 trillion in 2009. Aging civil infrastructure is calling for urgent measures focusing on maintenance, repair, and renovation.

For sustainable and resilient next-generation infrastructure systems with high long-term performance, it is imperative to develop better design, prediction, maintenance, life-cycle-cost-analysis and decision-making methodologies, and the success is premised up on the understanding of complicated long-term deterioration mechanisms of structures under various field conditions. Sensor-based instrumentation techniques coupled with Internet-enabled data communication techniques are commonly employed to obtain necessary quantitative measures of the progressive degradation of structures over time. In geomonitoring applications, however, the research community is caught overwhelmed with the complex and extensive nature of voluminous field sensor data associated with various factors of the deterioration of civil structures.

Unlike in the U.S.A., the monitoring of important civil infrastructure in Korea is mandated by laws. The government agencies and private companies have been archiving tremendous amounts of data collected at civil infrastructure systems for more than ten years, investing tens of millions of dollars. The planning visit was conducted to use the monitored data collected from various structural systems in Korea in order to apply, validate, and test our non-parametric methodologies. Without a priori information or physical assumptions on the structures of interest, which requires expensive field/laboratory measurements, the non-parametric approaches could be used to make useful engineering judgments using data from a minimal number of sensors. 

Our Korean counterparts’ rich data pools obtained from diverse sets of civil infrastructure systems (slopes, retaining walls, tunnels, bridges, etc) will play a crucial role in the development and validation of our non-parametric methodologies. Our planning visit Korea catalyzed international research collaboration with our Korean counterparts, involving government agencies, industry experts, and universities.

Our planning visit catalized international collaboration between U.S.A. and Korea in many aspects.  Rich and extensive monitored data collected from slopes, tunnels, subway, bridges, airport facilities, common utility ducts, and levees were shared to the PIs, and our data processing algorithms have been applied and studied using the monitored data.  So far, one peer-reviewed journal papers, one conference proceeding have been published and four invited lectures were made related to our planning visit. The list of publications and invited lectures is summarized at the end of the POR.  In addition, two visiting scholars from Korea Railroad Research Institute and Korea Institute of Construction Technology are currently visiting UCF for one year for collaborative research on civil infrastructure monitoring.

 

Refereed journal articles

1) H.-B. Yun and L.N. Reddi, “Non-parametric monitoring for geotechnical structures subject to long-term environmental change,” Advances in Civil Engineering, Vol. 2011, No. 275270, 17 pages, 2011

Publication in conference/workshop/symposia without proceedings 

1) H.-B. Yun, G. Sundaresan, ...
